title: How to watch and live stream the Tour de France 2023
content:
Cyclist
How to watch and live stream the Tour de France 2023

It’s back. The 2023 Tour de France begins on Saturday 1st July in Bilbao, Spain. Defending champion Jonas Vingegaard (Jumbo-Visma) will line up alongside two-time winner Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) in the fight for the maillot jaune, with Tour de Suisse winner Mattias Skjelmose (Lidl-Trek), Richard Carapaz (EF Education-EasyPost) and Ben O’Connor (AG2R-Citroën) among others looking to spoil their party.

The peloton will spend the first three days in the Basque Country. The iconic Col du Tourmalet features as early as Stage 6 with the return of the Puy de Dôme on Stage 9, before a selection of Tour classic climbs including the Grand Colombier, Col de Joux Plane and Col de la Loze will do their best to separate the general classification contenders on the way to climax in the Vosges mountains on Stage 20.

Along the way, keep an eye out for Mark Cavendish (Astana Qazaqstan) looking to break the stage win record he currently shares with Eddy Merckx, and a Fred Wright (Bahrain Victorious) breakaway in his new national champion’s kit. There’s also potentially a second season of Tour de France: Unchained being filmed for Netflix.

How to watch and live stream the Tour de France 2023

As always, live coverage of the 2023 Tour de France in the UK is on ITV4, S4C, GCN+ and Eurosport.

Eurosport and ITV4 will be providing extensive live coverage of all 21 stages as well as evening highlights. In the UK, ITV4 is a free-to-air channel and will be available on all UK television packages. Additionally, the racing can be seen live online on ITVX, which is also free.

The other option is streaming. The Eurosport coverage is streamed on Eurosport Player, Discovery+ and GCN+; these services offer uninterrupted live coverage and generally longer broadcasting than on terrestrial TV channels. GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year; Discovery+ and Eurosport Player are now the same service and cost £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like Wheeler Dealers and Naked and Afraid).

Streaming coverage via GCN+ will be available in select territories worldwide but not Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the USA. Double-check territory restrictions if you’re watching elsewhere to avoid disappointment.
